cards.desc:
So the framework has things such as h1's and .panel and .grid and these are in the Component Guide, and that is well. Also, things like EnterpriseReportingDatePicker and SimpleZebra Tables are in the Component Guide, and that is well.

The former are in a different subset than the latter. The **latter involve JavaScript** - at least for controlled, one-time instantiation. The **former are provided via CSS given a certain DOM contract/configuration**. The **former are also potentially modified further by a theme layout** for skinning or size alterations. The latter may also, but it is through JavaScript, which was the first distinction mentioned.

Put another way, they are the fundamental building blocks and so developers must be familiar with them. Those latter components are likely built upon these.

That said, they need their own page, even if the page is just the Component Guide prefiltered to show a tag set that contains them. Ordering might be an issue there though.
cards.name: Tag UI Base Components on Component Guide

cards.name: Add icons and better styling to link list component guide example

cards.desc:
/libs/lib-a.js
/libs/lib-b.js
/main.js

Right now, if lib-a and lib-b provide utilities that main.js uses, and they are all in the same namespace, then every file has to call wpt.namespace.

With a @requireAfter, the file would be required AFTER this file - letting us know our wpt.namespace call will be executed before our libs. As long as we wait until the appropriate time to USE those functions, then we know they will be there. (On ready, anytime other than immediate script invocation time)

@requireBefore would be identical to what we have now, like an alias.
cards.name: Consider @requireBefore/@requireAfter type annotation

cards.name: Fix SOAP Objective tab's inputs post-fix legend/label

cards.desc:
> InputOptions are strings that will be placed directly inside the HTML element to give further customization to the field. For example, maxlengths, sizes, DOM events, anything that can customize an element without the need for a completely new InputType and associated php code. The InputOptions not shown above is the following:

While we don't want to have to do heavy weight lifting for creating new InputTypes and associated php code, we also want to keep things DRY.

This means either we need a lighter weight vehicle for customization, or we need to better factor our input types.

This is likely as simple as moving the inline function calls, or calls passing the same variables, to javascript and point those elements to the js calls to enable them to all share the same function.

Or move the binding outside of inline events for performance and # of handlers.
cards.name: Identify common patterns in tests that should be refactored out into functions

cards.desc:
We really need to get the ball rolling regarding our reporting/bi solution. While Product decides what the company wants to do, we need to go on and prove out that we can do it. To prove that, let's pick something to do and prove it.

Ideally, we can use this solution to lead into the final solution once Product makes their decisions.

----------------------

A good example - good example of focusing on user: "Add Primary Physician - As a company administrator I want to know what referrals are a patient's primary physician, this way I can determine the frequency of new patients by a physician.

Acceptance Criteria: Indicate that a referring physician is primary"

Let's make a report which uses this information to easily show what % of referrals are by a primary physician, and if there are other ways to determining a new patient is coming by a physician (secondary?) the amount each contributes.
cards.name: Create Improved Referral Report Tech Demo

Reporting: Review referral-query-data-miner to see if its output over kafka should include any meta data or just raw data rows -- are data rows idempotent? How can we make them so? Is there a reliable hash we can generate for each row? (E.g. sha256 of simple concatenation of each column + time?)

A company level manager wants to see shrinkage across all clinics
A single clinic owner wants to compare how two ad campaigns are performing
A multi-clinic owner wants to compare how two ad campaigns are performing
A therapist wants to see how many people they have referred and whether or not they have been discharged or are inactive
A page that holds two charts and a datatable
A page that holds two charts and a datatable that are all linked together and update in unison.

A page that asks the user if they want to see things overall, or compare things. If they pick overall, they get a dashboard covering all time and the latest, most immediately useful stats. If they choose compare, we ask them how they want to compare things, and continue to ask until we drill down to good starting filters for that same dashboard page.

data.text: Cross linked charts means that when the filtering criteria changes, all of the charts update. This can be by passing them the data, or notifying them to read from a shared data store, or by some other mechanism. Crossfilter might play a role here, but ultimately things have to be done manually. We can generify after we've done it the first time.

This brings up an interesting issue of cross-theme components


What if all theme layouts defined all of their things, and then a theme layout consumer just used them to define itself?

Current theme layouts can be reproduced by consumers that just use their respective components.

Hybrid theme layouts can be produced by just using different components as needed.

....

maybe something like @extend .emr-theme-layout--panel

or useComponentFromTheme('emr', 'tab');

data.text: I have identified parallel tracks that can help move things faster.  Plus we should shoot for the correct, minimalist solution, and build it up from there.  For example, in context of the lambda architecture, maybe a couple hour delay in real-time report data is ok for initial release (i.e., build out batch and server layers), while the "speed layer" is being implemented for a follow-up release to merge in report data missed by batch computations, ultimately providing a complete, real-time reporting solution.  Baby steps!  :-)

data.text:
I want to create an Impact Analysis document and review it with Niagara before proceeding with actual transition work. For that document I need to explain what I plan to do. So I need to figure that out:

- JS is trying to change data by changing input values through the form DOMElement instance.
  - Select the element manually and change its value that way
  - Switch the data model to be JS driven over DOM driven
- JS is trying to store data on the form DOMElement instance
  - Are these just hidden inputs, or something else?
    - If hidden inputs, create or edit the inputs manually
    - If else, store the data on the SoapObj instance
- JS is trying to read data from the DOMElement instance
    - Pull directly from desired input DOM


Left off @ resources:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/Using_XMLHttpRequest#Submitting_forms_and_uploading_files

So jQuery('#addSOAP :input').serialize() looks promising!

Direct document.addSOAP / soapObj things break.

Plan looks to be:

- Refactor dependencies on FORM tag
  - Refactor the things that break
    - ICD Pickers
    - AutoSaver
    - confirmAlert(...), etc...
- Replace <form> with <div>
- Replace button submissions with AJAX
  - Ensure page redirection is handled properly upon success/failure
- Test across browsers
  - Test on iPAD!
  - Test in IE
  - Test in Safari
  - Test in FF
  - Test in Chrome

data.text:
Thinning things out into two buckets. If these don't replace our build system, I want our build system to utilize them or be utilized by them. At least Phing. I want it triggered by the same thing that triggers the rest.

-----------------------------
Pipeline Candidates:

Broccoli - Fast and composable, love that its *Tree based* instead of being *File based*. [Takes lessons from Grunt and Gulp](http://www.solitr.com/blog/2014/02/broccoli-first-release/).  **asset pipeline**

  Part of my idea is we will wrap OUR @require parser as a step in broccoli - similar to filter or such.

Grunt - Very verbose compared to something like Broccoli. Can run Broccoli.

Phing - Try using it to launch broccoli.

-----------------------------

Pipeline Node Candidates:

http://absurdjs.com/ - JS definitions define CSS and other parts of components. Really would be a module IN the pipeline - not the pipeline executor itself.

cardSource.name: Make jspackager manifests JSON driven

card.name: Make jspackager manifests JSON driven

data.text:
http://absurdjs.com/ - JS definitions define CSS and other parts of components. Really would be a module IN the pipeline - not the pipeline executor itself.

https://github.com/component/component - Not usable b/c of our dependencies on things like jQuery. It does not handle those well. We also use CSS preprocessors. It also relies on Github for its component registry. [Component versus other frameworks](https://github.com/component/guide/blob/master/component/vs.md) :-1:
 
Browserify - Oriented around Node in the browser. :-1:

Gulp - I like they embrace streaming as a first class citizen. Netflix uses them! :+1:

Broccoli - Fast and composable, love that its *Tree based* instead of being *File based*. [Takes lessons from Grunt and Gulp](http://www.solitr.com/blog/2014/02/broccoli-first-release/).  

Grunt - Very verbose compared to something like Broccoli.

almond.js - Would be great if it could handle example-multipage-shim, which would still have us manually declaring the dependencies, which we are already doing. :-1: 

Brunch - More like a mini static-ish site scaffolder. Would be great if our framework supported pages built using it! But not as a replacement for what we have. :smile: :-1:

data.text:
Component Guide Sections may consist of a taxonomy of different element types, which may recursively include each other to some extent (maybe we remove this ability for simplicity?). 

**Types**

- Typical Content
  - HTML/DOM
  - Grid
  - JS to instantiate
  - CSS Overrides
- Demos
  - HTML/DOM
  - Grid
  - JS to instantiate
  - CSS Overrides
  - Code Samples



Component Guide Section

Code Sample

- Foldable panel
  - Contents contains grid of different languages
  - Or panels linked together sitting in a grid
    - Could be simulated with first option by a transparent panel and each grid content defines its box to simulate individual panels
      - Or foldable logic should not be tied to panel

Demonstration

- Could just be a panel
- Biggest consideration is that it may need JS for instantiation or CSS overrides. Ideally these are coupled with the definition and not somewhere else where they may get out of sync. Or instead of them defining it a DSL could derive this. E.g. An array of component ids to instantiate and any additional config objects to instantiate them with
  - defineSection({
...
componentsUsed: ['comp-a', {}, 'comp-b', { emptyTableMessage: 'Please start a search first.' }]
...
});
  - How would we pass DOM references in such a case?
  - I should look back at AbsurdJS's component design, and Component's component design, and Bootstrap's for comparison

cardSource.name: Unify how demo sections are defined

card.name: Unify how demo sections are defined

data.text:
Can they be pieced together from simple components? As a composite component?
Panels, Grids

Should we have a registryAdd function or a factory function type thing and how would that look?

It would help enforce consistency and provide flexibility with changing its backend architecture if done right and consistently. It would start off with a mapping of slug id to object. Would need get and list functionality for other parameters or to hold multiple mappings.

Some things come to mind, like would there be different registries to add to, such as one for object definitions and one for current instances?

Singletons could be enforced by just always grabbing an ordered list of current component instances and grabbing the first if there is one or creating one otherwise. This way there is no magic that denies creating a second one - but convention says they won't be called. Or we could call all of them, and then it becomes like a message queue.

data.text:
One simple solution would be to just write a .tmp file out that is wiped upon each execution of the app. Simultaneous runnings may encounter issues unless each generates a time or guid in the filename though. That could hold the array of seen files.

Or PHP CLI script could hold the metadata in memory - this would be useful when combining batches of files with it. If holding the trees in memory does not work, trees could be given the ability to spit out a "seen files list" that is merged together to be used as the skip list.

This also means that the dep tree parser needs to be able to be given a skip list -- it needs to be able to expand that skip list out to the dependent files.

`Array of filename => array of filenames`

cardSource.name: Improve JsPackager's ability to skip/re-use already seen files

card.name: Improve JsPackager's ability to skip/re-use already seen files

data.text:
What if we had a @requireInline which actually injected the requested file right in place of that annotation?

Might work better for script rewriting if instead of an annotation it is a function call.

We could also make it use a callback, returning the contents of that file as the argument to the callback. This could be synchronous or asynchronous that way, and the written code would work. That implies the files are wrapped to return something, like a modules.exports.

Raw injection as first described would work without such modules.exports.


In the end, that freedom will be nice. I just hope I am not hurting us by not pushing us more towards AMD/CommonJS specs though.
